questions.text: 35-year-old Jenny presented with complaints of refractory vasomotor rhinitis, which is not better with medications and lifestyle modifications. The condition is affecting her day-to-day life and also causing complications like nasal polyps. After much implications, a surgical procedure called Vidian Neurectomy was considered. Anatomically, through which of the following foramina of the skull does the Vidian nerve pass?

A defect in one of her vertebrae is suspected to be the cause of her symptoms. To which landmark does the vertebra that is most likely to be the cause of symptoms corresponds?

questions.text: It has been one week since Ajmal underwent shoulder surgery. He presented to the OPD on an urgent basis now with complaints of transient pain in the wrist region. On examination, he was found to have weakness in the flexors of the thumb, index, and middle finger. Which could be the likely nerve affected?

options.label: D
options.text: Deep branch of the radial nerve

questions.text: You are in the anatomy museum studying a dissected heart. Which of the following is not a tributary/inlet of the right atrium?

50-year-old, previously diagnosed with Glioblastoma multiforme, now presented with some new symptoms. He has been experiencing memory loss along with unusual and unpredictable mood swings. The structure highlighted in the below figure is suspected to be involved. What type of fibre does this part categorize into? Figure 1: Reference: https://human-memory.net

A 45-year-old unidentified was the victim of a hit-and-run case. The patient was in hypotensive shock when he was brought to the hospital. After initial attempts at resuscitation, an X-ray venogram revealed a laceration of the Azygos vein. Where does this vein receive drainage from?

The glands in the human body can be divided into multiple types based on their mechanism of secretion. The given figure shows the histology of a part of the body. The pink arrows indicate a mechanism of secretion of the gland. What type of gland secretes contents in this manner?

John is an athlete who is very active professionally. Lately, however, he has been experiencing severe pain and numbness in his buttock region, radiating to his legs. It is often exacerbated in the sitting position and while running. After a detailed evaluation, he was diagnosed to have Piriformis syndrome. Which nerve is affected by this syndrome?

A 60-year-old had an untreated tooth infection of an upper molar. The infection has now spread to his neck, leading to cellulitis of the space within the cervical sheath. Which of the following structures is not a structure inside the sheath?

A head-and-neck oncology surgeon is doing a wide-radical neck dissection. She is focused on dissecting one of the anterior triangles. This particular triangle contains branches of the facial nerve, the submandibular gland anteriorly, and the lower part of the parotid gland posteriorly. Which muscle forms the floor of the triangle?

A 60-year-old woman presented with acute ataxia. Cerebellar tests like finger-nose and Romberg’s tests all indicated a cerebellar lesion. If the dorsal spinocerebellar tract is involved, which of the following statements are right about the tract?

options.label: A
options.text: The 1st neuron of the tract arises from the dorsal root ganglion.

options.label: B
options.text: They cross over in the lateral column of the spinal cord.

options.label: C
options.text: The 3rd neuron fibres relay at the posterolateral ventral nucleus of the thalamus.

options.label: D
options.text: The fibres relay pain and temperature.

questions.correct_answer: A. The 1st neuron of the tract arises from the dorsal root ganglion.

questions.text: The juxtaglomerular cells, given in the diagram below, produce an enzyme (x) that plays a vital role in blood pressure control by the kidney. It (x) helps control aldosterone production and regulates blood pressure. Which of the options below does not stimulate the enzyme ‘x’?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerve

  • Increased catecholamine
  • Prostaglandins

Inhibitory
  • Increased Na and Cl reabsorption across macula densa.
  • Increased afferent arteriolar pressure
  • Angiotensin II
  • Vasopressin

questions.text: An experiment is conducted to check the excitability of neurons. The effect of changing the concentration of different ions on excitability is noted. Among the following options, the change in concentration in which of the following ions affects the excitability of cells to the maximum limit?

A 28-year-old female athlete complains of muscle weakness and fatigue during exercise. She reports that she has been training intensively for the upcoming marathon for the past 3 months. A muscle biopsy is performed, and the results show a predominance of Type I muscle fibers. Which of the following statements best explains the muscle weakness and fatigue seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I muscle fibers are predominantly used for anaerobic exercise and are prone to fatigue.

options.label: B
options.text: Type I muscle fibers have a low oxidative capacity and are prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: Type I muscle fibers have a high oxidative capacity and are more resistant to fatigue than Type II fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: Type I muscle fibers have a high glycolytic capacity and are more resistant to fatigue than Type II fibers.

questions.correct_answer: B. Type I muscle fibers have a low oxidative capacity and are prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is not involved in calcium homeostasis ?
At which of the following blood pressure readings will the the baroreceptors be inactive?

55-year-old patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, indicating a likely myocardial infarction. The patient was immediately started on thrombolytic therapy, and his symptoms improved within a few hours. Which of the following changes would be expected in the patient's cardiac cycle following the myocardial infarction and subsequent thrombolytic therapy?
Which of the following are the actions/effects of endothelin-1?
questions.explanation:
Biologic effects of endothelins:
  • Hemodynamic effects:
  • Contracts vascular smooth muscle; veins more sensitive than arteries.
  • Cardiac effects:
  • Positive inotropic and chronotropic effects on the myocardium.
  • Intense vasoconstriction of coronary arteries
  • Neuroendocrine effects:
  • Increased plasma levels of ANP, renin, aldosterone, and catecholamines
  • Modulates synaptic transmission
  • Renal effects:
  • Increases renal vascular resistance
  • Decreases GFR, renal blood flow
  • Increases Na+ reabsorption through hemodynamic actions, but decreases Na+ reabsorption through inhibition of Na+-K+ pump.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. Upon examination, it is found that she has an irregular heartbeat and a grade III/VI systolic murmur. Further investigation revealed an enlarged left atrium and left ventricle with mitral valve regurgitation. A prominent third heart sound was heard during auscultation, followed by a fourth one. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's third and fourth heart sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: S3 is caused by left ventricular hypertrophy, while a stiff left ventricle causes S4 due to ischemic heart disease.

options.label: B
options.text: S3 is caused by increased atrial pressure, while a stiff left ventricle causes S4 due to hypertension.

options.label: C
options.text: S3 is caused by rapid ventricular filling, while S4 is caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle.

options.label: D
options.text: S3 is caused by decreased ventricular compliance, while S4 is caused by atrial contraction against a hypertrophied ventricle.

questions.correct_answer: C. S3 is caused by rapid ventricular filling, while S4 is caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient was diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder that affects the function of the Golgi apparatus. The Golgi apparatus is an essential organelle involved in the modification and sorting of proteins and lipids. The patient presents with symptoms such as impaired secretion of digestive enzymes, abnormal glycosylation of proteins, and reduced formation of lysosomes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying molecular defect in the patient's Golgi apparatus?
questions.correct_answer: C. Impaired function of mannosidase II

questions.text: A patient presents with extremely high LDL cholesterol levels in their blood, despite being on a low-cholesterol diet and taking a statin medication. Further investigation reveals the patient’s genetic mutation in the LDL receptor gene encoding. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced activity of HMG-CoA reductase leading to decreased cholesterol synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) activity leads to increased LDL cholesterol levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased hepatic lipase activity leads to decreased clearance of LDL cholesterol.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased expression or activity of LDL receptors leads to decreased LDL cholesterol clearance.

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased expression or activity of LDL receptors leads to decreased LDL cholesterol clearance.

questions.text: A researcher has isolated a liver cell from a fasting individual and analyzed the levels of various metabolites involved in gluconeogenesis. Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this cell? Metabolite Fasting levels Levels during gluconeogenesis Pyruvate ↓ ↑ Acetyl-CoA ↓ ↑ Oxaloacetate ↓ ↑ Fumarate ↑ ↓

A new drug is developed to target an enzyme involved in a critical metabolic pathway. In laboratory studies, the drug was found to inhibit the enzyme's activity by binding to a site that is not the active site but is close to it. Moreover, the drug's inhibition is not overcome in the presence of high substrate concentrations. Which type of inhibition does the drug exhibit?

A patient is diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder characterized by an increased sensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and a high risk of developing skin cancer. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of repair Cause Damage Disease
Nucleotide excision repair UV radiation damage T-T dimers Xeroderma pigmentosa
Base excision repair Spontaneous, IR rays, viral infection, chemical C → U conversion Rare, MUTYA associated polyposis

questions.text: A patient presents with a high level of acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate in the blood. Further examination reveals that the patient has been fasting for 72 hours. Which of the following enzymes would be activated in this scenario?

Glycogen Storage Disorders are a group of genetic diseases resulting from malfunctioning enzymes involved in glycogen metabolism. Von Gierke's disease is one such disorder that occurs due to the deficiency of a specific enzyme. Consider the following statements regarding Von Gierke's disease and choose the correct option(s): I. Von Gierke's disease is also known as Type I Glycogen Storage Disease. II. The disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. III. The deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease converts glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. IV. Von Gierke’s disease symptoms include hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia.

options.label: A
options.text: Statements I and III are true.

options.label: B
options.text: Statements I and IV are true.

options.label: C
options.text: Statements II and III are true.

options.label: D
options.text: Statements III and IV are true.

questions.correct_answer: B. Statements I and IV are true.

questions.text: Lysosomal Storage Disorders (LSDs) are a group of rare genetic disorders caused by defective lysosomal function, accumulating specific substances in various tissues and organs. Which of the following statements regarding LSDs is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Krabbe disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in various tissues and organs

options.label: B
options.text: Tay-Sachs disease is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons.

options.label: C
options.text: Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various tissues and organs

options.label: D
options.text: Hunter syndrome is caused by a deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in various tissues and organs

questions.correct_answer: A. Krabbe disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in various tissues and organs

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with weakness, fatigue, and dizziness symptoms. His medical history includes obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of ketone bodies in the blood and urine and low glucose levels. A diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is made, and the patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment. Which enzymes are responsible for the rate-limiting step in fatty acid oxidation?

A 58-year-old male patient presents with a history of unexplained weight loss, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Laboratory tests reveal high levels of lactate and pyruvate and low levels of ATP and NADH in his blood. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a genetic defect in one of the Krebs cycle enzymes. Which enzyme is most likely affected, and how does its dysfunction affect the patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Succinyl-CoA synthetase, leading to decreased energy production

options.label: B
options.text: Citrate synthase, leading to the accumulation of citrate

options.label: C
options.text: Isocitrate dehydrogenase, leading to decreased NADH production

options.label: D
options.text: Fumarase, leading to the accumulation of fumarate

questions.correct_answer: C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase, leading to decreased NADH production

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, fever, and sore throat for the past two weeks. He mentions that he has been feeling weak and has lost a few pounds. Upon physical examination, the doctor notes that the patient has enlarged tonsils with white patches, and tender lymph nodes in his neck. Blood tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count with atypical lymphocytosis. The doctor orders a heterophile antibody test, which comes back negative. What other tests can be ordered to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A throat culture to rule out bacterial pharyngitis

options.label: B
options.text: A rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

options.label: C
options.text: A viral capsid antigen (VCA) test for EBV

options.label: D
options.text: A complete blood count (CBC) with differential

questions.correct_answer: C. A viral capsid antigen (VCA) test for EBV

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with symptoms of jaundice, fatigue, and shortness of breath. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated bilirubin levels, and reticulocytosis. The peripheral blood smear given below. Family history reveals that her brother has a similar condition. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

A 25-year-old woman presents with symptoms of fever, chills, and severe abdominal pain. Her medical history reveals that she recently traveled to a rural area in Africa. Upon examination, the physician notes that the patient has an enlarged spleen and liver. Culture is done and colonies image is given below. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's symptoms?

A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?

A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with a history of a dirty wound on his foot. Laboratory investigations showed an elevated white blood cell count and presence of atypical lymphocytes. The smear findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the mode of action of the causative agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Tetanus caused by Clostridium tetani, which releases tetanospasmin

options.label: B
options.text: Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus, which infects B lymphocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Tetanus caused by Clostridium botulinum, which releases botulinum toxin

options.label: D
options.text: Mononucleosis caused by cytomegalovirus, which infects T lymphocytes

questions.correct_answer: A. Tetanus caused by Clostridium tetani, which releases tetanospasmin
questions.explanation:
Simple wound Other wound
Category A Nothing required Nothing required
Category B Toxoid 1 dose Toxoid 1 dose
Category C Toxoid 1 dose Toxoid 1 dose + HTIg
Category D Complete Toxoid dose Complete Toxoid dose + HTIg

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent fatigue and intermittent fevers. Laboratory investigations reveal a positive heterophile antibody test, elevated liver enzymes, and atypical lymphocytosis. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, which shows an increased number of reactive lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and confusion. His medical history is significant for recent travel to Southeast Asia. MRI of the brain shows hyperintense signals in the basal ganglia. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals elevated protein levels and pleocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

A 50-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash on her wrists and ankles. She reports that she recently went on a camping trip in a rural area.Upon physical examination, the patient has a temperature of 101.2°F and an enlarged spleen. Laboratory investigations reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test, and what is the recommended treatment for this condition?

A 28-year-old male presents to the hospital with a high-grade fever, severe headache, myalgia, and eschar on the left side of the chest. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. Serological testing shows positive IgM antibodies against Orientia tsutsugamushi. Which of the following is a common complication associated with scrub typhus infection that can present similarly to infectious mononucleosis, and how can it be differentiated?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemolytic anemia; by detecting the presence of autoantibodies against red blood cells

options.label: B
options.text: Guillain-Barré syndrome; by performing nerve conduction studies and cerebrospinal fluid analysis

options.label: C
options.text: Encephalitis; by performing a lumbar puncture and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Mononucleosis syndrome; by ruling out other etiologies of infectious mononucleosis and performing serological testing for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

questions.correct_answer: D. Mononucleosis syndrome; by ruling out other etiologies of infectious mononucleosis and performing serological testing for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the clinic with a dry cough, low-grade fever, and sore throat. She reports that her symptoms have been present for several weeks and have not improved despite taking over-the-counter cough suppressants. Upon physical examination, the patient appears well, with no evidence of respiratory distress. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with lymphocytosis, and chest X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this patient's symptoms, and how can it be diagnosed?

options.label: A
options.text: Mycoplasma pneumoniae; by performing serological testing for IgM antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: Streptococcus pneumoniae; by performing a sputum culture

options.label: C
options.text: Haemophilus influenzae; by performing a blood culture

options.label: D
options.text: Chlamydia pneumoniae; by performing a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on respiratory secretions

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe pruritus, erythema, and lichenification on her bilateral forearms and antecubital fossae. She reports a history of intermittent flares of similar symptoms for several years. The patient has tried multiple over-the-counter creams with little improvement. On physical examination, the affected areas show excoriations and scaling. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe a high-potency topical corticosteroid for long-term use

options.label: B
options.text: Perform patch testing to rule out contact dermatitis

options.label: C
options.text: Order a skin biopsy to rule out other skin conditions

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate treatment with a systemic immunosuppressant

questions.correct_answer: A. Prescribe a high-potency topical corticosteroid for long-term use

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with depigmented macules on his face, hands, and feet. The lesions have a sharp border and are symmetrically distributed. The patient reports that the depigmentation started a few years ago, and he has tried several over-the-counter treatments with no improvement. On examination, there is no erythema, scaling, or itchiness. Which of the following statements is true regarding the pathogenesis of vitiligo?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitiligo is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T-lymphocytes.

options.label: B
options.text: The primary pathophysiological mechanism of vitiligo is the destruction of melanocytes by autoimmune mechanisms.

options.label: C
options.text: The melanocytes in vitiligo are functionally normal, but factors secreted by T-lymphocytes inhibit their function.

options.label: D
options.text: The genetic susceptibility to vitiligo is linked to mutations in the CTLA4 gene.

questions.correct_answer: B. The primary pathophysiological mechanism of vitiligo is the destruction of melanocytes by autoimmune mechanisms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the dermatologic clinic for the evaluation of her facial rash. She denies any joint pain or photosensitivity. She does not have any oral lesions. On examination of the face, nodulocystic lesions are noted which are shown below: Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the drug of choice for her condition?

A 30-year-old male presents with gradual hair loss on his scalp for the past 2 years. He has no history of baldness in his family. Physical examination reveals diffuse hair loss with miniaturized hairs and a positive "pull test." Laboratory evaluation shows an increased serum level of Dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A fourth-year medical student appears for the viva voce examination in the final pathology examination. The professor asks him about different cell types and their role in acute inflammation. Which of the following is the best statement about cells and their role in inflammation?

options.label: A
options.text: In acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate in the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours

options.label: B
options.text: In acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate in the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 24 to 48 hours

options.label: C
options.text: In acute inflammation, monocytes predominate in the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: In acute inflammation, monocytes predominate in the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. In acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate in the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass on his neck. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathology report shows a "starry sky" pattern with numerous small, uniform lymphocytes and scattered large, pale-staining cells with basophilic nucleoli. Immunohistochemical staining reveals positivity for CD10, BCL6, and Ki-67. Flow cytometry shows expression of surface immunoglobulin and CD19, CD20, and CD22. What is the diagnosis, and what are the molecular and genetic abnormalities associated with this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Hodgkin lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells and CDKN2A

options.label: B
options.text: Follicular lymphoma, the t(14;18) translocation and BCL2

options.label: C
options.text: Mantle cell lymphoma, characterized by the overexpression of cyclin D1 due to the t(11;14) translocation

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of progressive weakness and tingling sensations in their legs that have gradually spread to their arms over the past few days. The patient also reports difficulty swallowing and speaking. On physical examination, the patient has diminished deep tendon reflexes and bilateral facial weakness. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

A 28-year-old female presents with a history of anemia and fatigue for several months. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Laboratory studies reveal low hemoglobin and serum iron levels, as well as elevated levels of transferrin and ferritin. A peripheral blood smear shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of iron absorption and transport that is impaired in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Transferrin-mediated transport across the intestinal mucosa

options.label: C
options.text: Endocytosis of heme by macrophages in the spleen

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilization of iron from intracellular ferritin stores

questions.text: A 25 year old women presents with recurrent abdominal pain and anaemia. Peripheral blood smear shows basophilic stippling of the RBCs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Inclusion Content
Howell- Jolly body DNA
Basophilic stippling RNA
Pappenheimer body Iron
Heinz body Denatured Hb
Cabot ring Mitotic spindle remnant

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of dark urine and abdominal pain over the last 6 months. She also reports fatigue, shortness of breath, and a history of thrombotic events. On examination, she has mild pallor and no significant lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, reticulocyte count of 6%, LDH level of 900 U/L, and a negative direct Coombs test. Flow cytometry analysis of peripheral blood shows a population of red blood cells with absent expression of CD55 and CD59. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 35-year-old female with a history of Hodgkin's lymphoma underwent an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from her HLA-matched sibling. The patient initially showed signs of engraftment and recovery, but on day +60 after HSCT, she presented with fever, skin rash, and diarrhea. On physical examination, diffuse erythematous macules and papules were seen on the skin. Laboratory tests showed pancytopenia, and a skin biopsy showed spongiosis and necrotic keratinocytes. A bone marrow biopsy revealed infiltration by donor-derived lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Transplant rejection
  Type Onset Mechanism & Vessel Histology Type of Hypersensitivity
“Host Vs Graft” Hyperacute Immediate Preformed antibodies directed against the donor tissue. Caused by accidental ABO blood type incompatibility which is very rare. Presents while still in surgery with thrombosis and occlusion of graft vessels II
Acute Weeks to months T-Cell mediated immune response directed against the foreign MHC. Inflammation and leukocyte infiltration of graft vessels results. Most common type. IV
Chronic Months to years T-Cell mediated process resulting from the foreign MHC "looking like" a self MHC carrying an antigen. Results in intimal thickening and fibrosis of graft vessels as well as graft atrophy III & IV
Graft Vs. Host Varies Donor T-Cells in the graft proliferate and attack the recipient's tissue. Most commonly seen in bone marrow transplants. Presents with diarrhea, rash and jaundice. IV

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a painless, slow-growing mass on his left lower lip that has been present for several months. On examination, a 2 cm ulcerated lesion with irregular borders and a firm base is noted. A biopsy of the lesion shows squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with the invasion of the deep submucosa. Further evaluation reveals cervical lymphadenopathy on the left side. Which of the following statements regarding SCC is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: SCC is the most common malignancy of the oral cavity

options.label: B
options.text: SCC of the lip is associated with a higher risk of metastasis than SCC of the oral cavity

options.label: C
options.text: SCC is typically preceded by leukoplakia or erythroplakia

options.label: D
options.text: SCC is associated with infection by the human papillomavirus (HPV)

questions.correct_answer: B. SCC of the lip is associated with a higher risk of metastasis than SCC of the oral cavity

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to extreme weakness. Physical examination revealed enlarged cervical lymph nodes and a palpable spleen 2 cm below the costal margin. Her haemoglobin level is 10.4 g/dl, the platelet count is 27 x 109/L, and the total leukocyte count is 40 x 109/L, with 80% mature lymphoid cells with coarsely clumped chromatin. A nodular lymphoid infiltrate is found in the bone marrow. The lymphoid cells in the peripheral blood are positive for CD19, CD5, CD20, and CD23 but negative for CD79B and FMC-7. In this patient, the HPE of the lymph node will most likely show effacement of lymph node architecture by?

options.label: A
options.text: A monomorphic lymphoid proliferation with admixed proliferation centres

options.label: B
options.text: A polymorphous population of lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils and scattered large binucleated cells

options.label: C
options.text: A predominantly follicular pattern with variably-sized follicles effacing nodal architecture

options.label: D
options.text: The diffuse proliferation of medium to large lymphoid cells with a high mitotic rate.

questions.correct_answer: A. A monomorphic lymphoid proliferation with admixed proliferation centres

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. He has a history of malabsorption syndrome and chronic diarrhea. His laboratory reports show low hemoglobin, serum iron, and ferritin levels. A bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of iron-laden macrophages. Which of the following mechanisms of iron absorption and transport is most likely impaired in this patient, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Transferrin-mediated transport of iron from the intestine into the blood

options.label: B
options.text: DMT1-mediated transport of iron from the intestine into enterocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Ferroportin-mediated transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood

options.label: D
options.text: Hepcidin-mediated regulation of ferroportin expression and iron release

questions.correct_answer: D. Hepcidin-mediated regulation of ferroportin expression and iron release

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a family history of colorectal cancer. His mother was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 35, and his brother was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 29. The patient reports having frequent episodes of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. A colonoscopy reveals hundreds of polyps throughout the colon. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible for the patient's condition?

A 1-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department by her parents with scaly skin lesions with purpuric rashes involving the scalp, abdomen, neck and face. She had a cough and was tachypneic. On physical examination, there is lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. On X-Ray of long bones, multiple lytic lesions are seen. What is the most likely cause of all this?

A 26-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss. She reports that these symptoms have been present for several months and have worsened over time. Her laboratory tests show a low serum iron level and a high level of tissue transglutaminase antibodies. She undergoes a duodenal biopsy, which reveals villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms and pathology, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

A 2-year-old child has been brought to the pediatric clinic with growth abnormalities. The examination shows open fontanelle, microcephaly, flat occiput, slanting palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, low set and malformed ears, protruding tongue, open mouth, and hypotonia. The child has been diagnosed with a cytogenetic disorder, the most common chromosomal disorder in humans and the most common inheritable cause ofmental retardation. The chromosome involved in this disorder belongs to which of the following subtypes of chromosomes?

A 64-year-old male presents to the clinic with com plaints of chronic cough, weight loss and hemoptysis . Bronchoscopy and histopathological biopsy are shown below. What are the most specific markers for this type of cancer?

A 29-year-old male patient's arterial phase CT of the spleen showed a lack of parenchymal enhancement that appeared Lardaceous. T2-weighted MR imaging showed decreased signal intensity . The given finding is due to deposition in which of the followings?

A 28-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient department for a routine check-up. She has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is currently taking oral corticosteroids. Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the hospital with a rash, fever, and joint pain. She reports having a recent travel history to a neighbouring country where there is a rubella outbreak. On examination, the patient is found to have enlarged lymph nodes and a rash on her face that has spread to her chest and arms. Laboratory tests reveal that the patient is positive for rubella IgM antibodies. Which of the following statements regarding rubella in pregnancy is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause stillbirth and neonatal death

options.label: B
options.text: Rubella infection during pregnancy has no adverse outcomes for the fetus

options.label: C
options.text: Rubella infection during the first trimester of pregnancy is less likely to cause congenital rubella syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Rubella infection during pregnancy is only a concern in the third trimester

questions.correct_answer: A. Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause stillbirth and neonatal death

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His electrocardiogram shows ST segment elevation consistent with acute myocardial infarction. In addition to standard treatment, which of the following interventions is most appropriate to reduce the patient's exposure to a common air pollutant that may exacerbate his cardiovascular disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Placement of an intra-aortic balloon pump

options.label: D
options.text: Transfer to a hospital located in an area with lower levels of particulate matter (PM2.5)

questions.correct_answer: D. Transfer to a hospital located in an area with lower levels of particulate matter (PM2.5)

questions.text: A study was conducted to investigate the association between smoking and lung cancer. The study included 1000 participants, 500 smokers and 500 non-smokers. After 10 years of follow-up, 100 cases of lung cancer were reported among smokers, and 25 cases of lung cancer were reported among non-smokers. What is the relative risk (RR) of lung cancer among smokers compared to non-smokers? What are the attributable risk (AR) and the population attributable risk (PAR)?

A case-control study was conducted to investigate the association between a rare disease and a potential risk factor. The study included 100 cases with the disease and 200 controls without the disease. Of the cases, 70 had been exposed to the risk factor, while only 30 of the controls had been exposed. Calculate the odds ratio for the association between the disease and the potential risk factor.
questions.explanation:
Odds Ratio Calculation 
Outcome 
Exposure  Cases Controls 
Exposed A B
Not Exposed C D

questions.text: A screening test is performed as a preventative measure to detect a potential health problem or disease in someone that does not yet have signs or symptoms. HIV is a disease that requires screening tests on a mass scale , especially in certain groups of people such as sex workers, IV drug abusers, and pregnant women. According to CDC recommendations, which of the following screening method is used for pregnant women ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Opt-in/Opt-out Testing
  • ➤ Opt-in/Opt-out Testing
  • ➤ Opt-in testing: Testing is offered and the patient is required to actively give permission before it can occur. Opt-out testing: Means performing an HIV test after notifying the patient that the test is normally performed, but that the patient may elect to decline or defer testing; assent is then assumed unless the patient declines testing. WHO and CDC recommends opt-out testing policies in health care settings. Opt- out testing has a higher (85-98%) testing rate than opt- in testing (25-83%). It does NOT eliminate the need for informed consent.
  • ➤ Opt-in testing: Testing is offered and the patient is required to actively give permission before it can occur.
  • ➤ Opt-out testing: Means performing an HIV test after notifying the patient that the test is normally performed, but that the patient may elect to decline or defer testing; assent is then assumed unless the patient declines testing. WHO and CDC recommends opt-out testing policies in health care settings. Opt- out testing has a higher (85-98%) testing rate than opt- in testing (25-83%). It does NOT eliminate the need for informed consent.
  • ➤ Opt-out testing:
  • ➤ WHO and CDC recommends opt-out testing policies in health care settings. Opt- out testing has a higher (85-98%) testing rate than opt- in testing (25-83%). It does NOT eliminate the need for informed consent.
  • ➤ WHO and CDC recommends opt-out testing policies in health care settings.
  • ➤ Opt- out testing has a higher (85-98%) testing rate than opt- in testing (25-83%).
  • ➤ It does NOT eliminate the need for informed consent.

questions.text: In a remote village of a developing country, a vaccination campaign is being conducted for children under the age of five. The vaccines are being transported in a cold chain, and each vaccine vial contains a VVM (vaccine vial monitor). The vaccinators, however, notice that some of the VVMs have turned black, indicating exposure to high temperatures. Which of the following actions should be taken in response, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Discard all of the vaccines with black VVMs and replace them with new vaccines.

options.label: B
options.text: Continue using the vaccines with black VVMs, as they may still be effective.

options.label: C
options.text: Conduct a temperature assessment of the storage and transport conditions to identify any issues.

options.label: D
options.text: Use the vaccines with black VVMs only on children who have already received one dose of the vaccine.

questions.correct_answer: C. Conduct a temperature assessment of the storage and transport conditions to identify any issues.

questions.text: A group of nutritionists are discussing the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for protein intake. One of the nutritionists argues that the RDA for protein intake should be increased for athletes, while another nutritionist argues that the RDA should be decreased for elderly people. The nutritionists cannot seem to agree on what the RDA for protein intake should be for different populations. Which of the following actions should the nutritionists take to determine the RDA for protein intake?

options.label: A
options.text: Use the same RDA for protein intake for all populations, regardless of age or activity level.

options.label: B
options.text: Conduct a study to determine the protein requirements for different populations.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a standard formula to calculate the RDA for protein intake based on body weight.

options.label: D
options.text: Rely on individual preferences and allow each person to determine their own protein intake.

questions.correct_answer: B. Conduct a study to determine the protein requirements for different populations.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option D:
    • Recommended Dietary Allowance for Protein  Children age 1-3 13 Children age 4-8 19 Children age 9-13 34 Girls age 14-18 46 Boys age 14-18 52 Women age 19-70+ 46 Men age 19-70+ 56

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol presents to a primary health care center with shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient is diagnosed with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and coronary artery disease (CAD). As a public health physician, which of the following is the most appropriate level of a prevention strategy to address this patient's conditions?

A 30-year-old man came to the OPD worried that he was going to a place where cholera is now on the rise. The doctor advised getting the cholera vaccine. Which of the following is not one of the vaccine strains for cholera?
questions.explanation:
Vaccine

Strain
BCG Danish 1331 (derived from M.bovis)

questions.text: Prevalence of a rare genetic disorder. Out of the 1000 individuals who participated in the study, 50 were found to have the disorder. A year later, a follow-up study was conducted in the same village to determine the incidence of the disorder. This study found that 10 new cases of the disorder had developed in the village. What is the incidence rate of the disorder in this village?

A 10-year-old child presents with a history of fever and a rash for the last 3 days. The rash is mainly on the trunk and spreads to the face and limbs. On examination, there are erythematous papules, vesicles, and crusts of different stages. The child has received one dose of the varicella vaccine at 1 year of age. Which of the following statements is true regarding this child's varicella-zoster virus (VZV)?

options.label: A
options.text: The child has primary varicella infection and is contagious.

options.label: B
options.text: The child has a breakthrough varicella infection and is not contagious

options.label: C
options.text: The child has varicella infection due to vaccine failure and is not contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The child has herpes zoster infection and is contagious.

questions.correct_answer: B. The child has a breakthrough varicella infection and is not contagious

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a head injury after falling from a height of 10 feet. On examination, the patient is unresponsive and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 6. The patient is intubated and taken for a CT scan showing a subdural hematoma. What is the significance of the patient's GCS score, and what is the appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A GCS score of 6 indicates mild head injury, and the patient can be managed conservatively.

options.label: B
options.text: A GCS score of 6 indicates severe head injury, and the patient requires urgent neurosurgical intervention.

options.label: C
options.text: A GCS score of 6 indicates moderate head injury, and the patient requires observation and serial neurological assessments.

options.label: D
options.text: A GCS score of 6 indicates no head injury, and the patient can be discharged after observation.

questions.correct_answer: B. A GCS score of 6 indicates severe head injury, and the patient requires urgent neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A community health worker reports that in a village, the number of maternal deaths in a year was 150. If the number of infants born in that year was 750, calculate the maternal mortality rate per 1,00,000.
questions.explanation:
Causes Percent of occurrence
Haemorrhage 24
Sepsis 15
Unsafe abortion 13
Hypertensive disorder 12
Obstructed labour 8
Indirect causes 20

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the relationship between physical activity and cardiovascular disease risk among adults aged 40-60 years. She collects data on the physical activity level (measured in minutes per week) and cardiovascular disease risk (measured using a standardized score) from a random sample of 200 individuals in the population. She calculates the mean physical activity level as 120 minutes per week and the standard deviation as 30 minutes per week. She also calculates the mean cardiovascular disease risk as 3.5 and the standard deviation as 0.5. Using this information, calculate the standard error of the mean for the physical activity level and cardiovascular disease risk.

options.label: A
options.text: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.035.

options.label: B
options.text: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071.

options.label: C
options.text: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.035.

options.label: D
options.text: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071.

questions.correct_answer: C. The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.035.

questions.text: What is the failure rate of male Condoms with typical use?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ PEARL INDEX OF DIFFERENT CONTRACEPTION:
  • ➤ PEARL INDEX OF DIFFERENT CONTRACEPTION:
  • ➤ Male condoms: 2-14/HWY [ 14- best answer] Female condoms: 5-21/HWY [ 21- best answer] IUD: 1-5 / HWY [ 2- best answer] OCPs: 0.1-2/HWY [ 1- best answer] Sterilization 0.1/HWY Vaginal sponge: 9-20/HWY

  • ➤ Vaginal sponge: 9-20/HWY
  • ➤ More effective method of sterilization is vasectomy > tubectomy.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the psychiatric outpatient department due to low mood for 5 weeks. It is associated with a lack of energy and appetite, poor concentration, and weight loss. She also reports suicidal intent. She is diagnosed with a case of major depressive disorder. She is to be started on fluoxetine. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of fluoxetine?

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine catabolism

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake

questions.text: A 22 years old male is brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of a change of behaviour. He is experiencing decreased sleep, increased sexual activity and enormous excitement. His parents say he has been spending excessively for 8 days and started gambling. During talks with the patient, the flight of ideas is noticeable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Mrs. X, a 28-year-old female, presents to the psychiatry outpatient department with a complaint of persistent feelings of emptiness, identity disturbance, and difficulty in maintaining stable relationships for the past five years. She has a history of impulsive behaviors such as binge-eating, substance abuse, and sexual promiscuity. She also reports a history of physical and emotional abuse during childhood. On examination, she appears anxious, avoids eye contact, and exhibits self-injurious behaviors. She is diagnosed with a personality disorder. Which of the following personality disorders is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 56-year-old female with a history of severe depression, suicidal ideation, and multiple failed medication trials presents to the psychiatric hospital for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). She has undergone ECT in the past with some improvement in her symptoms but has not had a treatment in over a year. On examination, she appears disheveled, and her affect is constricted. She reports feeling hopeless and has lost interest in her usual activities. Her laboratory workup is unremarkable. What are the indications for ECT in the treatment of depression, and what are the potential adverse effects of ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: ECT is indicated for treatment-resistant depression, and adverse effects include memory impairment, headache, and nausea.

options.label: B
options.text: ECT is indicated for moderate to severe depression, and adverse effects include cardiac arrhythmias, hypertension, and seizures.

options.label: C
options.text: ECT is indicated for severe depression with psychosis, and adverse effects include hypotension, bradycardia, and anemia.

options.label: D
options.text: ECT is indicated for mild to moderate depression, and adverse effects include increased appetite, weight gain, and hyperactivity.

questions.correct_answer: A. ECT is indicated for treatment-resistant depression, and adverse effects include memory impairment, headache, and nausea.

questions.text: After 5 days, the search team recovered the body of the 10-year-old boy who had gone missing while swimming in the lake. The skin of the boy showed signs of cutis anserina and the hands were seen clenched with weed and gravel in it. Which of the following findings would also be seen in a case of antemortem drowning?

A 55-year-old patient with a history of heart disease and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. The treating physician fails to order appropriate diagnostic tests and sends the patient home with instructions to take antacids. The patient subsequently suffers a heart attack and dies. Which is the most appropriate legal classification for the physician's actions?

A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. He reports that he ate some berries from a plant he found while hiking in the woods earlier that day. The image of the plant is given below. Which of the following is the primary toxin responsible for the patient's symptoms?

A 25-year-old male was involved in a car accident and suffered a blow to the head. CT scan revealed a linear fracture in the left temporal bone, extending to the petrous portion of the temporal bone. Which cranial nerves are most likely to be affected by this fracture?

A 35-year-old male was brought dead for post-mortem. On examination, he is cyanotic with petechiae in his face and conjunctiva. He had restricted blood flow to the brain and lungs. No toxic substance or presence of foreign object was detected in the airway passage.. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.explanation:
Form of asphyxia  Simplified definitions 
Hanging 
  • Neck compression/ Constriction d/t the suspension of the body (Complete or partial suspensions)
Strangulation 
  • Compression of the neck by any means other than body suspension 
  • It can be d/t ligature/ hands/ stick/ bend of elbow etc
Suffocation 
  • Obstruction to the airway by any means other than the neck constriction & body suspension is k/a suffocation

questions.text: A is charged with the murder of B. During the trial, the prosecution produces a letter allegedly written by A, in which A confesses to the murder. A claims that the letter is a forgery and denies writing it. Which of the following sections of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) is applicable in this case?

options.label: A

Antihypertensives, except ACEIs and ARBs Continue on the day of the surgery
Cardiac medicine, except β-blockers, digoxin Continue on the day of surgery
Antidepressants, anxiolytics, psychiatric medicine Continue on the day of surgery
Thyroid medicine Continue on the day of surgery
OCP Continue on the day of surgery
Eye drops Continue on the day of surgery
Heartburn/reflux medicine Continue on the day of surgery
Opioid medicine Continue on the day of surgery
Anticonvulsants Continue on the day of surgery
Asthma medicine Continue on the day of surgery
Corticosteroids(oral/inhaled) Continue on the day of surgery
Statins Continue on the day of surgery
Aspirin Continue on the day of surgery with prior percutaneous coronary intervention, high-grade IHD, and significant CVD. Otherwise, discontinue 3 days before the surgery.
P2Y12 inhibitors (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, prasugrel, ticlopidine) Stop clopidogrel 5-7 days before.
Stop ticagrelor 5-7 days before.
Stop prasugrel 7-10 days before. 
Stop ticlopidine 10 days before. 
Exceptions- Patients who have had drug-eluting stents should not stop these medicines before 6 months of completing therapy.
Insulin Short-acting insulin- discontinue on the day of surgery.
Long-acting insulin- ½ dose in Type 2 DM. 1/3 dose in type 1 DM.
Continue if the patient has a continuous insulin pump
Topical medicine  Discontinue on the day of surgery
Non-insulin antidiabetic medication Discontinue on the day of surgery.
Exceptions- SGLT2 inhibitors should be stopped 24 hours before.
Diuretics Discontinue on the day of surgery. 
Exceptions- Thiazides be continued on the day of surgery
Sildenafil Discontinue on the day of surgery
COX-2 inhibitors Continue on the day of surgery
NSAIDs Discontinue 48 hours before surgery
Warfarin Discontinue 5 days before surgery
MAO inhibitor Continue medications but adjust anaesthesia accordingly

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl went to the pediatric clinic with concerns about her height. Her parents report that she has always been shorter than her peers and is now being teased at school. On examination, the girl is found to be at the 3rd percentile for height and weight. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her short stature?
questions.explanation:
Cause of Short Stature

Description

Constitutional Growth Delay

A common cause of short stature in children; is delayed growth spurt, eventually reaching the target height but later than peers.

Familial Short Stature

Short stature runs in the family, but no underlying medical condition.

Growth Hormone Deficiency

A rare condition caused by a lack of growth hormone may be associated with other signs/symptoms.

Hypothyroidism

Can cause growth retardation, usually associated with other signs/symptoms such as fatigue, constipation, and dry skin.

Turner Syndrome

A genetic disorder affecting only females, caused by the absence or partial absence of one X chromosome, short stature, and other physical abnormalities.

Noonan Syndrome

A genetic disorder affecting both males and females, caused by mutations in several genes, short stature, distinctive facial features, and other physical abnormalities.

Achondroplasia

A genetic disorder causing abnormal bone growth, short limbs, average-sized trunk, and other physical abnormalities

Intrauterine Growth Restriction

Fetal growth is restricted due to factors such as maternal illness, placental insufficiency, or fetal abnormalities.

Chronic Disease

Chronic diseases can affect growth and development, including cystic fibrosis, renal disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.

Malnutrition

Inadequate nutrition can lead to stunted growth.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. An ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). The infant undergoes surgery, and the surgeon is about to make the incision when they realize that an unusually large and prominent duodenal bulb is present. How should the surgeon proceed with the operation to avoid any complications?

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis presents with acute hematemesis. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 beats/min. options.text: The patient's condition deteriorated due to a secondary infection, which caused the tube to move out of position. Antibiotics should be given prophylactically

options.text: The patient might have pulled the tube accidentally, causing it to move out of position. The tube should be secured properly to prevent accidental dislodgment

options.label: D
options.text: The tube was inserted too deeply, causing it to coil in the stomach. The depth of insertion should be checked before the tube is secured

questions.correct_answer: D. The tube was inserted too deeply, causing it to coil in the stomach. The depth of insertion should be checked before the tube is secured

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing surgery for a perforated peptic ulcer. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed that the patient had an allergy to silk sutures, which were the planned suture material. The surgical team needs to choose an alternative suture material to use. Which of the following suture materials would be the best alternative for the surgeon to use in this situation?

A 35-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. On imaging, a type IV-A choledochal cyst is detected. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement

options.label: D
options.text: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) with stent placement

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgical excision of the cyst

questions.text: A natural disaster has occurred, and a triage team is set up at a local hospital to assess and prioritize patients. The team consists of a senior physician, a nurse, and a paramedic. The team is presented with five patients at once, all with different injuries. Patient 1: A 45-year-old male with a severe head injury, unconscious and unresponsive. Patient 2: A 20-year-old female with a fractured leg and bleeding wound. Patient 3: A 30-year-old male with minor cuts and bruises. Patient 4: A 70-year-old female with chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient 5: A 10-year-old male with a broken arm. What should the triage team do first?

options.label: A
options.text: Assess patient 1 and provide immediate medical attention.

options.label: B
options.text: Assess patient 4 as she is elderly and may be experiencing a cardiac emergency.

options.label: C
options.text: Assess patient 5 as he is a child and may be more vulnerable to trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: Assess patient 2 as she has a life-threatening injury and needs immediate attention.

questions.correct_answer: D. Assess patient 2 as she has a life-threatening injury and needs immediate attention.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. On examination, he is found to have a palpable bladder, and a post-void residual volume of 40 mL is measured on ultrasound. Further imaging given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this neonate?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate insertion of a suprapubic catheter

options.label: C
options.text: Placement of a Foley catheter for urinary drainage

questions.correct_answer: C. Placement of a Foley catheter for urinary drainage

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a left testicular mass that was found incidentally during a routine physical examination. Ultrasound of the scrotum shows a solid mass in the left testicle with areas of calcification. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase. The patient undergoes orchiectomy, and pathology confirms a seminoma. Further imaging reveals no evidence of metastasis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Seminoma Nonseminomatous
  Localized to the testis Extended to the epididymis, scrotal sac, and more.
Stage I and II II or III
Metastasis Lymphatic Lymphatic
Hematogenous to lung or liver
 
Prognosis Good Varies

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated for 2 episodes of projectile vomiting , which started 5 hours after the delivery. Vomitus is green in color and half a cup in quantity. He was born at 35 weeks of gestation via caesarian section due to placental insufficiency causing fetal distress. The abdomen is distended . An X-ray abdomen image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female accompanied by her husband presents to Gynaecology OPD for contraceptive counselling. She has been married for 6 years, and her last childbirth was 1 year ago. She has 4 live children with one abortion. Also, she was concerned about limiting her family from having no contraindications for oral contraceptive pills. It has been explained that the failure rate of contraceptive pills is less than 1 per Hundred Woman Years. How can the failure rate be calculated?

options.label: A
options.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / number of women observed x Total months of contraceptive use.

options.label: B
options.text: Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.

options.label: C
options.text: Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.

options.label: D
options.text: Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / number of women observed x Total months of contraceptive use.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with concerns about her recent pregnancy test results. She is 6 weeks pregnant and reports experiencing spotting and mild cramping. Her serum hCG levels were measured twice, 48 hours apart, with the second measurement showing a 35% increase compared to the first. Based on this information, which of the following conditions is most likely?

A 24-year-old primigravida woman at 26 weeks of gestation comes in for a routine antenatal visit. On clinical examination, her fundal height measures 30 cm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal fundal height for gestational age

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman at 38 weeks of gestation with gestational diabetes is undergoing a non-stress test (NST) as part of her antenatal care. The cardiotocography (CTG) tracing shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 135 bpm, moderate variability, and three accelerations of at least 15 bpm lasting for 15 seconds within a 20-minute period. No decelerations are noted. How would you interpret these NST results?

A 28-year-old primigravida woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents with a confirmed breech presentation to her healthcare provider. She has no significant medical history, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Trial of labor and vaginal delivery

questions.explanation:
Type of Breech Presentation Description General Management Approach
Frank breech The fetus's buttocks are closest to the cervix, and the legs are extended straight up in front of the body, with the feet near the head.
  1. Attempt external cephalic version (ECV) at 36-37 weeks of gestation in uncomplicated pregnancies.
  2. Consider a trial of labor and vaginal delivery with an experienced healthcare provider in select cases.
  3. Opt for cesarean delivery if ECV is unsuccessful or contraindicated or if there are other risk factors or complications.
Complete breech The fetus's buttocks are closest to the cervix, and the legs are folded at the knees, with the feet near the buttocks.
  1. Attempt external cephalic version (ECV) at 36-37 weeks of gestation in uncomplicated pregnancies.
  2. Cesarean delivery is typically preferred due to the increased risk of complications during vaginal delivery.
  3. Opt for cesarean delivery if ECV is unsuccessful or contraindicated or if there are other risk factors or complications.
Footling breech One or both of the fetus's feet are closest to the cervix rather than the buttocks.
  1. External cephalic version (ECV) may be less successful in footling breech presentations but can still be attempted in select cases.
  2. Cesarean delivery is generally recommended due to the higher risk of complications, such as cord prolapse and birth trauma, associated with vaginal delivery.
  3. Opt for cesarean delivery if ECV is unsuccessful or contraindicated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with regular contractions. Her cervix is 4 cm dilated, and the contractions are occurring every 5 minutes. Four hours later, her contractions continue every 5 minutes, but her cervical dilation has only progressed to 5 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor

options.label: C
options.text: Encourage ambulation and reevaluate in 2 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor
questions.explanation:
Latent phase  Cervical dilatation £ 3cm
  • Lasts around 8 hours
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour given only in this phase 
Active phase Cervical dilatation ³ 4cm 
  • Lasts around 4-6 hours
  • Ocolytics in preterm labour cannot be given in active phase 
  • Future divided into 
    • Acceleration phase 
    • Phase of maximum slope 
    • Deceleration phase 
First From onset of true labour pain to full cervical dilatatioin
Second  Full cervical dilatation to delivery of baby 
Third  Delivery of baby to delivery of plecenta 
Fourth  Stage of observation, till 1 hour after delivery of placenta 

Maximum duration (Stage I & Stage II of labor combined): 
Nulliparous  Mean - 9 hours  Upper - limit 18.5 hrs.
Multiparous  Mean - 6 hours  Upper - limit 13.5 hrs.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with regular contractions. The healthcare provider begins monitoring her labor progress using a partograph. Four hours after admission, her contractions occur every 5 minutes, and her cervix is 6 cm dilated. The fetal heart rate is normal, and the descent of the fetal head is progressing adequately. However, the patient's contractions cross the action line on the partograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to monitor labor without intervention

options.label: B
options.text: Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor

options.label: D
options.text: Administer intravenous fluids and reevaluate in one hour

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 39 weeks of gestation is in the second stage of labor. The fetal heart rate is normal, and the fetus is descending in the birth canal. The patient has been pushing for 1 hour, and the healthcare provider notices significant perineal stretching with a risk of perineal tearing. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to monitor labor without intervention

options.label: C
options.text: Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor

questions.explanation:

Wound extension  More Common  Less Common

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with spontaneous rupture of membranes. On examination, the healthcare provider notices a loop of umbilical cord protruding from the vagina. The fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most appropriate course of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Manual reduction of the prolapsed cord

options.label: C
options.text: Administer tocolytics and continue to monitor the patient

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding is diagnosed with a large intramural fibroid. She is nulliparous and desires to preserve her fertility. Which of the following treatment options would be the most appropriate for her?

A 28-year-old woman with a history of irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and obesity is diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). She is not planning to conceive in the near future but is concerned about the long-term health consequences of PCOS. Which management strategies would be the most appropriate for this patient?

14-year-old girl presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and a webbed neck. Chromosomal analysis reveals a 45, X karyotype, confirming a diagnosis of Turner syndrome. The patient's mother is concerned about potential complications associated with Turner syndrome. Which of the following long-term complications has the highest prevalence in patients with Turner syndrome?

A 19-year-old female primigravida from poor socio-economic background comes to the OPD for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks gestation. Ultrasound revealed a gap in the fetal spine through which the spinal cord and meninges protrude. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old girl was presented to the OP for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. Clinical examination showed normally developed breasts and thin pubic hair. Examination revealed well-developed labia and a short vagina which ended blindly. Cervix was not visualized. She had a history of bilateral inguinal hernias, which were surgically repaired at the age of 2. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the OP for evaluation of secondary amenorrhea. She had a history of incomplete abortion 4 years back, which was evacuated using D & C. She has been having oligomenorrhea for the past 2 years and is now presenting with amenorrhea. What could be the most likely cause?

A 23-year-old female comes to the OP with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks back, and she is worried that she might get pregnant. Which of the following methods cannot be advised to this patient?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with a history of osteoporosis and multiple vertebral fractures. She is currently taking bisphosphonates for the management of her condition. On laboratory investigation, it is found that the patient has developed hypocalcemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue bisphosphonates and initiate teriparatide therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Add calcium and vitamin D supplementation to the patient's regimen

questions.correct_answer: C. Add calcium and vitamin D supplementation to the patient's regimen

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus has an HbA1c level of 8.5% despite maximum tolerated doses of metformin and a sulfonylurea. Which of the following statements regarding DPP4 inhibitors is false?

options.label: A
options.text: DPP4 inhibitors stimulate insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells

options.label: B
options.text: DPP4 inhibitors block the degradation of endogenous incretin hormones

options.label: C
options.text: DPP4 inhibitors have a low risk of causing hypoglycemia

options.label: D

questions.text: A patient with liver disease is prescribed a new drug for their condition. The drug undergoes extensive metabolism in the liver through various phase reactions before being eliminated from the body. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding drug metabolism and phase reactions in the liver of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Phase I reactions involve the conversion of lipophilic drugs into more polar metabolites through oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis

options.label: B
options.text: Phase II reactions involve the conjugation of drugs with endogenous compounds, such as glucuronic acid, sulfate, and glutathione

options.label: C
options.text: In liver disease, phase II reactions are impaired while phase I reactions remain intact

options.label: D
options.text: The metabolism of drugs in the liver is affected by genetic polymorphisms in drug-metabolizing enzymes

questions.correct_answer: C. In liver disease, phase II reactions are impaired while phase I reactions remain intact

A 70-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and gastric ulcer is prescribed with a medication that needs to be administered via the oral route. However, the physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of oral administration of the drug on the patient's gastric ulcer. The physician also wants to ensure optimal absorption of the drug into the systemic circulation. Which of the following routes of drug administration would be the most appropriate for this patient?
